issues.title: Frontend: Add Required Footer Elements(if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
If this is a frontend project, ensure it has a proper footer with all required elements.

## Tasks
- [ ] Verify footer exists on all pages
- [ ] Add copyright statement: "© 2025 AOSSIE"
- [ ] Add "KYA (Know Your Assumptions)" link/element
- [ ] Ensure footer is consistent across all pages

## Requirements
All AOSSIE frontends must include:
- Copyright statement: `© 2025 AOSSIE`
- KYA (Know Your Assumptions)

## Resources
- [Bene](https://ergo.bene.stability.nexus/) for Ergo is a project that does KYA very nicely, as a modal that is shown when the user first visits the website and also when the user clicks the link in the footer. We should follow this approach.
- [KYA Template](https://github.com/StabilityNexus/Info/blob/main/KYA.md) - Use this template for creating your KYA content.

**Note**: If this is not a frontend project, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Frontend: Implement Responsive Design for Mobile (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Ensure the frontend displays properly across all screen sizes, especially mobile devices. Many AOSSIE projects have frontends where element sizes do not adjust well for smaller screens.

## Tasks
- [ ] Audit all pages for mobile responsiveness
- [ ] Implement responsive CSS using media queries or modern frameworks
- [ ] Test on various screen sizes (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [ ] Ensure touch-friendly interactive elements (minimum 44x44px)
- [ ] Fix any text overflow or layout breaking issues
- [ ] Optimize images for different screen sizes
- [ ] Test on actual mobile devices (iOS and Android)
- [ ] Ensure proper viewport meta tag is set
- [ ] Verify navigation/menu works well on mobile
- [ ] Check that all buttons and forms are easily usable on mobile

## Best Practices
- Use mobile-first approach
- Use relative units (rem, em, %, vw, vh) instead of fixed pixels
- Test across multiple devices and browsers
- Consider using CSS frameworks with built-in responsiveness
- Ensure proper spacing and padding for touch targets

## Resources
- [Responsive Web Design Basics](https://web.dev/responsive-web-design-basics/)
- [MDN Responsive Design Guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/CSS_layout/Responsive_Design)

**Note**: If this is not a frontend project, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Add Token List Support for ERC20 Selection (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
If this is an EVM-based blockchain project that allows users to deploy contracts with custom ERC20 tokens, improve the user experience by allowing users to select tokens from a curated list in addition to manually inputting contract addresses.

## Context
Currently, some AOSSIE EVM-based projects only support manual ERC20 contract address input. Users should also be able to choose from a pre-populated list of supported tokens for better UX.

## Tasks
- [ ] Check if this project involves ERC20 token selection for contract deployment
- [ ] Integrate the StabilityNexus TokenList
- [ ] Implement UI dropdown/selector for supported tokens
- [ ] Keep the option for manual contract address input
- [ ] Validate manually entered contract addresses
- [ ] Add token logo/icon display in the selector
- [ ] Implement token search/filter functionality
- [ ] Add proper error handling for invalid addresses
- [ ] Test with various tokens from the list
- [ ] Update documentation with new token selection feature

## Benefits
- Improved user experience
- Reduced errors from manual address input
- Visual token identification with logos
- Faster token selection

## Resources
- [StabilityNexus TokenList](https://github.com/StabilityNexus/TokenList) - Check README for integration details and supported tokens

**Note**: If this is not an EVM-based blockchain project, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Backend: Implement Consistent Error Handling
issues.body:
## Description
Standardize error handling across the entire application (backend and frontend) to ensure consistent user experience and easier debugging.

## Tasks
- [ ] Define standard error response format (status code, message, error code)
- [ ] Implement centralized error handling middleware/utilities
- [ ] Create custom error classes for different error types
- [ ] Add proper HTTP status codes for all error scenarios
- [ ] Implement user-friendly error messages for frontend
- [ ] Add detailed error logging for debugging
- [ ] Handle validation errors consistently
- [ ] Implement global error boundaries (frontend)
- [ ] Add error monitoring/tracking integration
- [ ] Document error codes and their meanings
- [ ] Test error scenarios thoroughly

## Best Practices
- Never expose sensitive information in error messages
- Use appropriate HTTP status codes
- Log errors with context (request ID, user ID, timestamp)
- Provide actionable error messages to users
- Differentiate between client and server errors

## Resources
- [HTTP Status Codes Guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status)
- [Error Handling Best Practices](https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/error-handling-in-javascript/)

issues.title: Backend: Add API Rate Limiting (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Implement rate limiting on API endpoints to prevent abuse, DDoS attacks, and ensure fair usage across all users.

## Tasks
- [ ] Identify endpoints that need rate limiting
- [ ] Choose rate limiting strategy (IP-based, user-based, or both)
- [ ] Implement rate limiting middleware
- [ ] Define rate limits for different endpoint types
- [ ] Add proper HTTP 429 responses when limit exceeded
- [ ] Include rate limit headers (X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset)
- [ ] Implement different tiers for authenticated vs anonymous users
- [ ] Add rate limit monitoring and alerts
- [ ] Document rate limits in API documentation
- [ ] Test rate limiting behavior
- [ ] Consider implementing exponential backoff suggestions

## Recommended Limits
- Public endpoints: 100 requests per 15 minutes
- Authenticated users: 1000 requests per hour
- Admin/privileged users: Higher or no limits

## Resources
- [Rate Limiting Strategies](https://cloud.google.com/architecture/rate-limiting-strategies-techniques)

**Note**: If this project doesn't have an API backend, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Gas Optimization Audit (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Audit and optimize smart contract gas usage to reduce transaction costs for users. This is an ongoing task where community members can continuously suggest optimizations.

## Tasks
- [ ] Run gas reporter on all contract functions
- [ ] Identify gas-heavy operations
- [ ] Optimize storage usage (use packed structs, minimize storage writes)
- [ ] Use memory instead of storage where appropriate
- [ ] Optimize loops and iterations
- [ ] Use appropriate data types (uint256 vs smaller types)
- [ ] Remove unnecessary operations and redundant checks
- [ ] Consider using libraries for common operations
- [ ] Batch operations where possible
- [ ] Optimize modifier usage
- [ ] Use events instead of storage for historical data
- [ ] Document gas costs for major operations
- [ ] Compare gas usage before/after optimizations

## Ongoing Optimization
This issue can remain open for community members to continuously suggest and implement gas optimizations as new patterns emerge.

## Resources
- [Gas Optimization Techniques](https://www.rareskills.io/post/gas-optimization)
- [OpenZeppelin Gas Optimization Tips](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/api/utils)

**Note**: If this project doesn't involve smart contracts, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Security Audit Checklist (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Review smart contracts for common vulnerabilities and security issues to ensure safe deployment and operation.

## Security Checks
- [ ] Reentrancy protection (use ReentrancyGuard)
- [ ] Integer overflow/underflow (use SafeMath or Solidity 0.8+)
- [ ] Access control mechanisms properly implemented
- [ ] Input validation on all external functions
- [ ] Check for unchecked return values
- [ ] Verify proper use of tx.origin vs msg.sender
- [ ] Review delegatecall usage for security
- [ ] Check for front-running vulnerabilities
- [ ] Verify timestamp dependence issues
- [ ] Review randomness generation (avoid block.timestamp)
- [ ] Check for denial of service vulnerabilities
- [ ] Verify proper event logging
- [ ] Review upgrade mechanisms (if proxy pattern used)
- [ ] Check for signature replay attacks
- [ ] Verify proper handling of ETH/token transfers

## Audit Steps
- [ ] Run automated security tools (Slither, Mythril, etc.)
- [ ] Manual code review by team members
- [ ] Consider professional third-party audit
- [ ] Create security documentation
- [ ] Setup bug bounty program

## Resources
- [Smart Contract Security Best Practices](https://consensys.github.io/smart-contract-best-practices/)
- [SWC Registry - Vulnerability Classification](https://swcregistry.io/)
- [OpenZeppelin Security Tools](https://www.openzeppelin.com/security-audits)
- [Slither Documentation](https://github.com/crytic/slither)

**Note**: If this project doesn't involve smart contracts, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Handle Network Switching Gracefully (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
If this is a blockchain frontend project, implement proper handling when users switch networks in their wallet to ensure smooth user experience and prevent errors.

## Tasks
- [ ] Detect network changes in wallet
- [ ] Display current network to user
- [ ] Show warning when user is on wrong network
- [ ] Implement automatic network switching prompt
- [ ] Handle unsupported networks gracefully
- [ ] Pause/disable actions when on wrong network
- [ ] Update UI state when network changes
- [ ] Re-fetch data after network switch
- [ ] Clear cached data specific to previous network
- [ ] Test switching between different networks
- [ ] Add network configuration for all supported chains
- [ ] Implement fallback RPC endpoints
- [ ] Display network-specific information (gas prices, block time)

## Best Practices
- Never assume the network won't change
- Always validate network before transactions
- Provide clear feedback about required network
- Store network-specific data separately

## Resources
- [MetaMask Network Detection](https://docs.metamask.io/wallet/how-to/detect-network/)
- [Wagmi Network Handling](https://wagmi.sh/react/hooks/useNetwork)

**Note**: If this is not a blockchain frontend project, you can close this issue.
